the italian language is a romance language based on the ancient Latin spoke by aristocrats and the one spoken by the Volgo also called Volgare, which it is presumed to be a normal SVO way to speak latin (subject object verb). In the italian language articles are very common, and you have nouns divided into Feminine and Masculine (there is no Neuter). the alphabet has 21 letters, but 26 like english if you count the foreign based words. All the vowels are pronounced very openly and every single letter in every word is pronounced and never skipped. Double consonants are very frequent but to pronounce them correctly it's like there's a little stop ' . "Mattone" (brick) is pronounced ---> Mà'tone [it's like there is a little stop]. To begin with actualy italian you have to know that this language follows the SVO method, Subject Verb Object, Verbs come in conjugations for every person and they have 21 different tenses divided in 7 groups and different for 3 groups of verbs called -are, -ere and -ire based on their suffixes to distinguish them and to know how to conjugate them.
Personal pronouns are:
Io I
Tu You
Lui/ Lei He/ She
Noi We
Voi You all
Loro They

( Lei it's a formal way to talk to someone directly instead of Tu (you) ; in the south though instead of Lei it is used Voi )
irregular verbs exist with their different conjugations but to start a language you don't have to learn every single tense to complicate your life, you can just start with the present tense and go on from there.
It's very simple, with the Personal pronouns now you can see how conjugations work for the present tense, we said that the conjugations group are 3 so let's see:
[since you have conjugations you can omit the personal pronouns in sentences and it would still be correct, usually you say the personal pronoun to accentuate]
[also before the suffix -are you will see the stem of the verb, it will never change, you just have to learn the various endings based on the group and tense. to conclude when a stem ends with a vowel you must not put 2 same vowels near eachother because that's something that never occures in the italian language, if you have Mangiare (mangi-are, to eat) if you have endings starting with "i" you remove cette "i" to not double the same vowel]

-are ---> Cant-are (to sing)
Io cant-o
tu cant-i
lui cant-a
noi cant-iamo
voi cant-ate
loro cant-ano



-ere ---> Cad-ere (to fall)
io cad-o
tu cad-i
lui cad-e
noi cad-iamo
voi cad-ete
loro cad-ono


-ire ---> Dorm-ire (to sleep)
io dorm-o
tu dorm-i
lui dorm-e
noi dorm-iamo
voi dorm-ite
loro dorm-ono


Irregular To be ----> Essere
io sono
tu sei
lui è
noi siamo
voi siete
loro sono


irregular to have ----> Avere
io ho
tu hai
lui ha
noi abbiamo
voi avete
loro hanno


Articles on the other hand are also very useful; they are divided in Masculine Feminine, Singular and Plural:

Definites: ("The" in english)
Sing. Plural
Masculine (starting with consonants) Il I
Masculine (starting with sp. sounds) Lo Gli
Masculine (starting with vowels) L' Gli
Feminine (starting with consonants) La Le
Feminine (starting with vowels) L' Le

Indefinites: ("a/an" in english)
Sing.
Masculine (starting with consonants) Un
Masculine (starting with sp. sounds) Uno
Masculine (starting with vowels) Un
Feminine (starting with consonants) Una
Feminine (starting with vowels) Un'


Nouns also usually when they end with -a they're Feminine and in -o they're Masculine, but take the Usually in mind because they can also have other endings to which they'll have other plural formation, but to remain simple these Singular endings are a great start to learn first.
Basic vocabulary to start making sentences as examples:
Mela ----> Apple
Libro ----> Book
Albero ----> Tree
Pesca ----> Peach
Uomo ----> Man
Donna ----> Woman
Ragazzo/a ----> Boy/Girl [just change the ending]

so if we take the verbs that i've talked about before

Io sono un uomo
I am a man

this is a sentence you could already make on your own with everything that i've said
let's see another

io mangio una mela
i eat an apple

same with this one, you ask me why?
let's break this down:
Io ----> I I listed the personal pronouns so if you study them you should know them
Mangio ----> It's easy, i said before that Mangiare was "to eat", i've shown you the conjugation for -are verbs so just add that -o at the end of its stem and you've got yourself a conjugated verb to the first singular person
una ----> indefinite article which i've listed before
mela ----> apple was in the vocabulary which i also listed before

start making simple sentences on your own and to grow one step at a time search English/Italian dictionary to search for new words to make these random sentences and after mastering these basics you can go further to search for other stuff to learn.

My grandpa died of Alzheimer's around month ago. Surprisingly, he lasted more than 14 years since he had been diagnosed, and although it wasn't very extreme, the last year got very harsh. In the last few months, he had completely forgotten who any of us were (myself, my sister, my mother, his other daughters, his wife, etc), where he was, and what he was doing. He constantly had the urge to leave and "go home." From what we understood, he thought he was still a kid and wanted to go back to his childhood home, and sometimes he even cried for his mother. His very last month got the most harsh. He had to be sent to the hospital multiple times. The only thing he remembered was his name during the last visit to the hospital. After his last visit, my mom and her two sisters were already preparing what he'll be wearing during his funeral. He had completely forgotten how to speak or interact. The last few days before he died, he fell in a coma. In short, he had no idea what was going on around him, the only thing he did was respond with sounds when he was hurting. His lungs got clogged up because he forgot how to swallow properly and all of his food went to his lungs instead. I believe that this was also the reason why he passed away.

The sad thing about Alzheimer's is that it slowly drains the person away. Unlike other diseases which kill the person on the spot, Alzheimer's slowly and painfully drains the person like a sponge, until they forget their basic human functions and who they are. What kills them isn't Alzheimer's itself, but the effects of it. This is at least my point of view from my experience. Either way, I am grateful that people like Michael exist, big influencers who use their fame for a good cause. I've seen many different fundraisers, but I have to say that Alzheimer's is one that touches me the most, which is why I will definitely consider donating. I could care less about the beard hair, the cause is what makes it all worth it. Thank you Michael for this fundraiser. It truly means a lot to me and other people who's loved ones were victims of Alzheimer's.

Regarding Alzheimer's.

I won't say all, but in reviewing the research, most seems to be caused by:

• Metabolic dysfunction
• Inflammation
• Toxins


Metabolic being the largest factor. Insulin resistance being a symptom. Excessive Vegetable oils, actually seed and bean oils, are very harmful due to their excessive Polyunsaturated fats(PUFA) content, particularly linoleic acid. We eat 10-20x of these as we did in the 1800's, before we had the current chronic diseases.

Processed carbs, play a role as well, in the short term, but pale in comparison to excessive PUFA long term.

Excess PUFA is the root cause of most chronic disease.

The mechanisms are well documented in the literature at this point.

Inflammation is a factor, but this is predominantly, thought not exclusively, excess PUFA as well.

Toxins is from mold, bacteria, and heavy metals.
Interestingly, oxidized linoleic acid, an omega-6 PUFA, and it metabolites, also are a toxin. They even have their own name in the literature, OXLAM'S.
